title: A story connecting centuries
content: This is the story of two women Hannie, a freed slave, and Benny, a first year high school English teacher. The story centers around the need to find “our people”. Hannie does that while on an adventure risking her life to find the family that was separated from her through slave sales.  She becomes the keeper of the Book of Lost Friends - actual newspaper articles from post Civil War times of freed slaves searching for information about separated family members.  Benny begins her teaching career in a poor Louisiana school trying to reach students through the importance of stories. She enlists the help of community members to share the past with her students. This ignites a fire in her students and the research begins. The reader soon realizes everything for both characters is connected to Goswood Grove Plantation in their small town in Louisiana.

title: Verified Purchase
content: I just cannot say enough positive things about this book. I've read fiction my whole life and have always enjoyed historical fiction. This book is easily one of my favorites of all time. I have long thought that writing fiction takes incredible talent. Writing historical fiction is an art form in and of itself. From the research necessary to frame the story accurately to the intentional use of language to suit time periods, historical fiction is just another level of writing. Lisa takes us to another time and puts us in the same air as the characters in the book as we learn things now known before or, in my case, not fully appreciated before. As is the case with all wonderful books, I was sad when it ended and found myself hoping to learn more as I shall now that I know where to start.  I've recommended this book to many friends and contacts as I very much look forward to Lisa's future labors of love as she transports us to other times with other people from whom we learn.

title: Verified Purchase
content: The Book of Lost Friends is a moving story of people in two different time lines who live both inside their own “ time constraints “ and overlap in the reader’s mind. The characters are well developed and interesting.  The author’s research into the time periods is obvious and enhances the story.  The stories are told in chapters that flip back and forth in time.  I especially enjoyed that the return to the previous time period never smoothly segued but jumped or jolted into the action making me have to make up some of what I perceived as missing pieces in my own mind.  It seemed like a sense of trust that the author gave the reader.  Ms Wingate wrote so skillfully with enough material in each chapter about the characters and their story that it was obvious what was happening without cluttering their story with unnecessary descriptions.  I thoroughly appreciated this author’s talent.  Thank you for your contribution to literature, Ms Wingate.

title: Verified Purchase
content: Wingate has once again delivered a powerful tale; this time a work depicting the realities surrounding freed slaves, scattered through the deep south, trying to survive and reconnect with their loved ones during the post-civil war era.  In a juxtaposition of present-day narration, Miss Silva, a first-year teacher hiding painful memories and a dark secret from her past, alternates with flashback chapters one hundred years prior; the young heroine, Hannie- a slave freed as a result of the civil war, setting out on a journey to protect the promise of a livelihood after hard years’ of share cropping.  The two stories weave together while heightening the connection between the two eras, exposing the prejudice in both our past and those which continue to cling to present-day society.  Historical fact combines with richly vivid characters created by the author.  Having a ‘so pleased to have found this book’ feeling, my recommendation for you to read it couldn't be stronger! I view this novel as a wonderful choice for book clubs.  It just begs to be discussed, digested and reflected upon!

title: Verified Purchase
content: I really enjoy historical fiction, especially when the book teaches you new information about something. It is difficult to find new windows of history that haven't been explored in a fictional format and this is one of those rare books that does just that. The Book of Lost Friends was a slave's handwritten journal that contained names of the slaves separated from their families by being sold. Post Civil War, the slaves were searching for their lost family members and friends. Advertisements were placed in the newspaper and then read in churches on Sundays. With so much social media and technology today, it may be hard to imagine having to use such a slow and seemingly impossible method. But as the story shows, where there is a strong will, there will be a way. I found this to be a very interesting and touching story. I highly recommend it!

title: Did Not Compare to Before We Were Yours
content: I loved this book and I learned from it.  With people about whom I cared and adventures that drew me in, I learned what the Reconstruction period was really like in the South and especially for Black people.  they'd been freed and abandoned to fend for themselves in lawless territories.  As freed slave Hannie Gossett travels through Texas searching for her former master and her family members pulled from her at slave auctions, we learn of the cruelty, brutality, danger, and terror of freed slaves with no money, land, or family to which to cling.  The modern day descendants of those slaves and some of their white neighbors delve into their forebears' stories at the direction of Benny Silva, their teacher in 1987 Louisiana.  We learn as they do.  This is a fascinating book that has opened a window for me that I hadn't known was closed.  It's a great , absorbing read and I highly recommend it.

title: Verified Purchase
content: I thoroughly enjoyed this book.  I'm not always a fan of books that jump between time frames, but I thought this was very well done.  Both stories were so engaging that I looked forward to getting back to them as I finished each chapter.  I thought they came together beautifully, quite masterfully, in tying up the details of both stories.  While I was aware that many slave families were separated from each other, I did not know of the efforts they later made to find each other after slavery was abolished.  This book did such an excellent job of illustrating how that was done while highlighting the emotion and trauma endured by families torn apart.  The subject matter of both stories in this book is sensitive but relevant and the author does a superb job of demonstrating many of the challenges in the slow process of recovering from the evils of slavery.

title: Lisa Winngate Never Disappoints
content: I could hardly put this book down!  The author follows the lives of two women, one a former slave from post Civil War times and her journey from Louisianna into the still unsettled Texas to  find her missing master with two unlikely companions, a woman who she once was the personal slave to as a child, and the daughter of the "master," conceived with a one of the slaves and supported secretly by the the master. The other is a Bennie  a first year teacher in a  poor small high school in the 1080s in Louisianna.  The stories soon begin to intertwine when Bennie, the teacher, challenges her students to learn the history of the people in their town.  Students soon learn why both blacks and whites in their community have the same last names.  Lost Friends was an actual newspaper column where freed slaves searched for their families that had been sold off to different "masters."  A unique story for anyone who enjoys historical fiction!
